column1: It is the part of wise parents to repress these squibs and crackers of juvenile contention
column2: and to enforce that slowly learned lesson
column3: that in this world one must often "pass over" and "put up with" things in other people
column4: being oneself by no means perfect. Also that it is a kindness
column6: to let people think and say and do things in their own way occasionally.But even if Mr. and Mrs. Skratdj had ever thought of teaching all this to their children
column7: it must be confessed that the lesson would not have come with a good grace from either of them
column8: since they snapped and snarled between themselves as much or more than their children in the nursery.The two elders were the leaders in the nursery squabbles. Between these
column10: a ceaseless war of words was waged from morning to night. And as neither of them lacked ready wit
column11: and both were in constant practice
column12: the art of snapping was cultivated by them to the highest pitch.It began at breakfast
column13: if not sooner."You've taken my chair.""It's not your chair."
